abstract.text: A layout object that organizes items into a grid with optional header and footer views for each section.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A flow layout is a type of collection view layout. Items in the collection view flow from one row or column (depending on the scrolling direction) to the next, with each row containing as many cells as will fit. Cells can be the same sizes or different sizes.
A flow layout works with the collection view’s delegate object to determine the size of items, headers, and footers in each section and grid. That delegate object must conform to the

protocol. Use of the delegate allows you to adjust layout information dynamically. For example, you use a delegate object to specify different sizes for items in the grid. If you don’t provide a delegate, the flow layout uses the default values you set in the properties of this class.

Flow layouts lay out their content using a fixed distance in one direction and a scrollable distance in the other. For example, in a vertically scrolling grid, the width of the grid content is constrained to the width of the corresponding collection view while the height of the content adjusts dynamically to match the number of sections and items in the grid. The layout scrolls vertically by default, but you can configure the scrolling direction using the

Each section in a flow layout can have its own custom header and footer. To configure the header or footer for a view, configure the size of the header or footer to be non-zero. Implement the appropriate delegate methods or assign appropriate values to the
properties. If the header or footer size is
, the corresponding view isn’t added to the collection view.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
Constants that indicate the direction of scrolling for the layout.
The methods that let you coordinate with a flow layout object to implement a grid-based layout.
A layout object that organizes items into a grid with optional header and footer views for each section.
Constants that describe the reference point of the section insets.
A placeholder size for self-sizing cells.
The estimated size of cells in the collection view.
The default sizes to use for section footers.
The default sizes to use for section headers.
The default size to use for cells.
The minimum spacing to use between items in the same row.
The minimum spacing to use between lines of items in the grid.
The scroll direction of the grid.
A Boolean value that indicates whether footers pin to the bottom of the collection view bounds during scrolling.
A Boolean value that indicates whether headers pin to the top of the collection view bounds during scrolling.
The margins used to lay out content in a section.
The boundary that section insets are defined in relation to.
A set of properties for determining whether to recompute the size of items or their position in the layout.
An abstract base class for generating layout information for a collection view.
A layout object that manages the layout-related attributes for a given item in a collection view.
A special type of layout object that lets you implement behaviors when changing from one layout to another in your collection view.
Customize a view layout by changing the size of cells in the flow or implementing a mosaic style.
Constants that specify the types of supplementary views that can be presented using a flow layout.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
